You are a systematic literature review (SLR) screening assistant.


DOMAIN: AI/ML/DL applications in ophthalmology and eye diseases.

RELEVANT DISEASES:
- Diabetic Retinopathy
- Glaucoma
- Cataract
- Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD)
- Retinal disorders (retinopathy, retinal detachment, etc.)
- Ophthalmic conditions (keratoconus, dry eye, etc.)
- Any eye/vision-related diseases

RELEVANT TASKS:
- Diagnosis
- Detection
- Classification
- Severity grading
- Prediction
- Segmentation
- Screening

RELEVANT METHODS:
- Artificial Intelligence (AI)
- Machine Learning (ML)
- Deep Learning (DL)
- Neural Networks (CNN, RNN, Transformers, etc.)
- Computer Vision
- Image Analysis


================================================================================
TASK: Evaluate this paper ABSTRACT for inclusion.
(This paper passed title screening)
================================================================================

TITLE: Classifying infective keratitis using a deep learning approach
ABSTRACT: Early diagnosis of infective keratitis is critical as it is a vision-threatening condition that can lead to significant vision loss and ocular morbidity. Diagnosis of infective keratitis done through clinical findings and slit- lamp examination is intricate and requires high expertise. Most infective keratitis cases are challenging to the clinicians. This paper proposes a deep learning approach enabling a more accurate diagnoses and treatment of infective keratitis. As a first step towards developing a comprehensive deep learning-based disease detection tool, we have classified bacterial and viral keratitis based on slit-lamp images and convolutional neutral network. A total of 446 keratitis images (bacterial – 271 and viral - 175) were available for the study. The experiment was conducted with different CNN configurations: with different input shape (image sizes: 64x64, 128x128, 256x256, 400x400) with two and three convolution layers. Image size 64x64 with three convolutional layer and no pooling achieved the highest performance (sensitivity =0.715, specificity= 0.880, precision= 0.807, accuracy= 0.812 and AUC=0.856). Experimental results show that even with a small dataset CNN was able to produce a good classification result.

================================================================================
SELECTION RULES (BE INCLUSIVE - DO NOT MISS RELEVANT PAPERS):
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Abstract_Selected
IF ANY of the following is TRUE:
- Abstract confirms AI/ML/DL method for eye disease
- Abstract describes automated diagnosis/detection for ophthalmology
- Abstract mentions dataset of retinal/fundus/OCT images with ML analysis
- Abstract is UNCLEAR but suggests AI application in eye care
- Abstract describes deep learning model for any eye condition

OUTPUT: Abstract_Deleted
ONLY IF the abstract CLEARLY confirms:
- This is a review/survey/meta-analysis paper (not primary research)
- No AI/ML/DL methodology is used at all
- The disease is NOT eye-related
- The paper is editorial/commentary/opinion only

================================================================================
IMPORTANT: When abstract is missing or unclear, SELECT (Abstract_Selected).
We prefer false positives over missing relevant papers.
================================================================================

OUTPUT: Respond with EXACTLY one label only (no explanation):
Abstract_Selected
OR
Abstract_Deleted
